an6.44:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena migasālāya upāsikāya nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
an6.44:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the laywoman Migasālā, where he sat on the seat spread out.

an6.44:1.2.pli: Atha kho migasālā upāsikā yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho migasālā upāsikā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an6.44:1.2.eng: Then the laywoman Migasālā went up to Ānanda, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an6.44:2.1.pli: “Kathaṃ kathaṃ nāmāyaṃ, bhante ānanda, bhagavatā dhammo desito aññeyyo, yatra hi nāma brahmacārī ca abrahmacārī ca ubho samasamagatikā bhavissanti abhisamparāyaṃ?
an6.44:2.1.eng: “Honorable Ānanda, how on earth are we supposed to understand the teaching taught by the Buddha, when the chaste and the unchaste are both reborn in exactly the same place in the next life?

an6.44:2.2.pli: Pitā me, bhante, purāṇo brahmacārī ahosi ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
an6.44:2.2.eng: My father Purāṇa was chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.

an6.44:2.3.pli: So kālaṅkato bhagavatā byākato sakadāgāmī satto tusitaṃ kāyaṃ upapannoti.
an6.44:2.3.eng: When he passed away the Buddha declared that, since he was a once-returner, he was reborn in the host of joyful gods.

an6.44:2.4.pli: Petteyyopi me, bhante, isidatto abrahmacārī ahosi sadārasantuṭṭho.
an6.44:2.4.eng: But my uncle Isidatta was not chaste; he lived content with his wife.

an6.44:2.5.pli: Sopi kālaṅkato bhagavatā byākato sakadāgāmipatto tusitaṃ kāyaṃ upapannoti.
an6.44:2.5.eng: When he passed away the Buddha declared that, since he was also a once-returner, he was reborn in the host of joyful gods.

an6.44:2.6.pli: Kathaṃ kathaṃ nāmāyaṃ, bhante ānanda, bhagavatā dhammo desito aññeyyo, yatra hi nāma brahmacārī ca abrahmacārī ca ubho samasamagatikā bhavissanti abhisamparāyan”ti?
an6.44:2.6.eng: How on earth are we supposed to understand the teaching taught by the Buddha, when the chaste and the unchaste are both reborn in exactly the same place in the next life?”

an6.44:2.7.eng: “You’re right, sister, but that’s how the Buddha declared it.”

an6.44:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando migasālāya upāsikāya nivesane piṇḍapātaṃ gahetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.
an6.44:3.1.eng: Then Ānanda, after receiving almsfood at Migasālā’s home, rose from his seat and left.

an6.44:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an6.44:3.2.eng: Then after the meal, on his return from almsround, Ānanda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

an6.44:4.1.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena migasālāya upāsikāya nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdiṃ.

an6.44:4.2.pli: Atha kho, bhante, migasālā upāsikā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho, bhante, migasālā upāsikā maṃ etadavoca:

an6.44:4.3.pli: ‘kathaṃ kathaṃ nāmāyaṃ, bhante ānanda, bhagavatā dhammo desito aññeyyo, yatra hi nāma brahmacārī ca abrahmacārī ca ubho samasamagatikā bhavissanti abhisamparāyaṃ.

an6.44:4.4.pli: Pitā me, bhante, purāṇo brahmacārī ahosi ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.

an6.44:4.5.pli: So kālaṅkato bhagavatā byākato sakadāgāmipatto tusitaṃ kāyaṃ upapannoti.

an6.44:4.6.pli: Petteyyopi me, bhante, isidatto abrahmacārī ahosi sadārasantuṭṭho.

an6.44:4.7.pli: Sopi kālaṅkato bhagavatā byākato sakadāgāmipatto tusitaṃ kāyaṃ upapannoti.

an6.44:4.8.pli: Kathaṃ kathaṃ nāmāyaṃ, bhante ānanda, bhagavatā dhammo desito aññeyyo, yatra hi nāma brahmacārī ca abrahmacārī ca ubho samasamagatikā bhavissanti abhisamparāyan’ti?

an6.44:4.9.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, migasālaṃ upāsikaṃ etadavocaṃ:

an6.44:5.1.pli: “Kā cānanda, migasālā upāsikā bālā abyattā ammakā ammakapaññā, ke ca purisapuggalaparopariyañāṇe?
an6.44:5.1.eng: “Ānanda, who is this laywoman Migasālā, a foolish incompetent aunty, with an aunty’s wit? And who is it that knows how to assess individual persons?

an6.44:5.2.pli: Chayime, ānanda, puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an6.44:5.2.eng: These six individuals are found in the world.

an6.44:6.2.pli: Idhānanda, ekacco puggalo sorato hoti sukhasaṃvāso, abhinandanti sabrahmacārī ekattavāsena.
an6.44:6.2.eng: Take a certain individual who is gentle and pleasant to be with. And spiritual companions enjoy living together with them.

an6.44:6.3.pli: Tassa savanenapi akataṃ hoti, bāhusaccenapi akataṃ hoti, diṭṭhiyāpi appaṭividdhaṃ hoti, sāmāyikampi vimuttiṃ na labhati.
an6.44:6.3.eng: And they’ve not listened or learned or penetrated theoretically or found even temporary freedom.

an6.44:6.4.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā hānāya pareti no visesāya, hānagāmīyeva hoti no visesagāmī.
an6.44:6.4.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they depart for a lower place, not a higher. They’re going to a lower place, not a higher.

an6.44:7.1.pli: Idha panānanda, ekacco puggalo sorato hoti sukhasaṃvāso, abhinandanti sabrahmacārī ekattavāsena.
an6.44:7.1.eng: Take another individual who is gentle and pleasant to be with. And spiritual companions enjoy living together with them.

an6.44:7.2.pli: Tassa savanenapi kataṃ hoti, bāhusaccenapi kataṃ hoti, diṭṭhiyāpi paṭividdhaṃ hoti, sāmāyikampi vimuttiṃ labhati.
an6.44:7.2.eng: And they’ve listened and learned and penetrated theoretically and found temporary freedom.

an6.44:7.3.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā visesāya pareti no hānāya, visesagāmīyeva hoti no hānagāmī.
an6.44:7.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they depart for a higher place, not a lower. They’re going to a higher place, not a lower.

an6.44:8.2.pli: ‘imassapi teva dhammā aparassapi teva dhammā, kasmā tesaṃ eko hīno eko paṇīto’ti.
an6.44:8.2.eng: ‘This one has just the same qualities as the other, so why is one worse and one better?’

an6.44:8.3.pli: Tañhi tesaṃ, ānanda, hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
an6.44:8.3.eng: This will be for their lasting harm and suffering.

an6.44:9.1.pli: Tatrānanda, yvāyaṃ puggalo sorato hoti sukhasaṃvāso, abhinandanti sabrahmacārī ekattavāsena, tassa savanenapi kataṃ hoti, bāhusaccenapi kataṃ hoti, diṭṭhiyāpi paṭividdhaṃ hoti, sāmāyikampi vimuttiṃ labhati.
an6.44:9.1.eng: In this case, the individual who is gentle … and has listened, learned, comprehended theoretically, and found temporary freedom

an6.44:9.2.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, puggalo amunā purimena puggalena abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca.
an6.44:9.2.eng: is better and finer than the other individual.

an6.44:9.4.eng: Because the stream of the teaching carries them along.

an6.44:9.5.eng: But who knows the difference between them except a Realized One?

an6.44:9.6.eng: So, Ānanda, don’t be judgmental about individuals.

an6.44:9.8.eng: Those who pass judgment on individuals harm themselves.

an6.44:9.9.pli: Ahaṃ vā, ānanda, puggalesu pamāṇaṃ gaṇheyyaṃ, yo vā panassa mādiso.
an6.44:9.9.eng: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on individuals.

an6.44:10.1.pli: Idha panānanda, ekaccassa puggalassa kodhamāno adhigato hoti, samayena samayañcassa lobhadhammā uppajjanti.
an6.44:10.1.eng: Take another individual who is angry and conceited, and from time to time has greedy thoughts.

an6.44:10.2.pli: Tassa savanenapi akataṃ hoti, bāhusaccenapi akataṃ hoti, diṭṭhiyāpi appaṭividdhaṃ hoti, sāmāyikampi vimuttiṃ na labhati.
an6.44:10.2.eng: And they’ve not listened or learned or penetrated theoretically or found even temporary freedom.

an6.44:10.3.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā hānāya pareti no visesāya, hānagāmīyeva hoti no visesagāmī.
an6.44:10.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they depart for a lower place, not a higher. They’re going to a lower place, not a higher.

an6.44:11.1.pli: Idha panānanda, ekaccassa puggalassa kodhamāno adhigato hoti, samayena samayañcassa lobhadhammā uppajjanti.
an6.44:11.1.eng: Take another individual who is angry and conceited, and from time to time has greedy thoughts. …

an6.44:11.2.eng: Because the stream of the teaching carries them along. …

an6.44:11.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re headed for a higher place, not a lower. They’re going to a higher place, not a lower.

an6.44:12.2.eng: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on people.

an6.44:13.1.pli: Idha panānanda, ekaccassa puggalassa kodhamāno adhigato hoti, samayena samayañcassa vacīsaṅkhārā uppajjanti.
an6.44:13.1.eng: Take another individual who is angry and conceited, and from time to time has the impulse to speak inappropriately.

an6.44:13.2.pli: Tassa savanenapi akataṃ hoti …pe… sāmāyikampi vimuttiṃ na labhati.
an6.44:13.2.eng: And they’ve not listened or learned or penetrated theoretically or found even temporary freedom.

an6.44:13.3.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā hānāya pareti no visesāya, hānagāmīyeva hoti no visesagāmī.
an6.44:13.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they depart for a lower place, not a higher. They’re going to a lower place, not a higher.

an6.44:14.1.pli: Idha panānanda, ekaccassa puggalassa kodhamāno adhigato hoti, samayena samayañcassa vacīsaṅkhārā uppajjanti.
an6.44:14.1.eng: Take another individual who is angry and conceited, and from time to time has the impulse to speak inappropriately.

an6.44:14.2.pli: Tassa savanenapi kataṃ hoti, bāhusaccenapi kataṃ hoti, diṭṭhiyāpi paṭividdhaṃ hoti, sāmāyikampi vimuttiṃ labhati.
an6.44:14.2.eng: But they’ve listened and learned and penetrated theoretically and found temporary freedom.

an6.44:14.3.pli: So kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā visesāya pareti no hānāya, visesagāmīyeva hoti no hānagāmī.
an6.44:14.3.eng: When their body breaks up, after death, they depart for a higher place, not a lower. They’re going to a higher place, not a lower.

an6.44:15.2.pli: ‘imassapi teva dhammā, aparassapi teva dhammā. Kasmā tesaṃ eko hīno, eko paṇīto’ti?
an6.44:15.2.eng: ‘This one has just the same qualities as the other, so why is one worse and one better?’

an6.44:15.3.pli: Tañhi tesaṃ, ānanda, hoti dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya.
an6.44:15.3.eng: This will be for their lasting harm and suffering.

an6.44:16.1.pli: Tatrānanda, yassa puggalassa kodhamāno adhigato hoti, samayena samayañcassa vacīsaṅkhārā uppajjanti, tassa savanenapi kataṃ hoti, bāhusaccenapi kataṃ hoti, diṭṭhiyāpi paṭividdhaṃ hoti, sāmāyikampi vimuttiṃ labhati.
an6.44:16.1.eng: In this case, the individual who is angry and conceited, but has listened, learned, comprehended theoretically, and found temporary freedom

an6.44:16.2.pli: Ayaṃ, ānanda, puggalo amunā purimena puggalena abhikkantataro ca paṇītataro ca.
an6.44:16.2.eng: is better and finer than the other individual.

an6.44:16.4.eng: Because the stream of the teaching carries them along.

an6.44:16.5.eng: But who knows the difference between them except a Realized One?

an6.44:16.6.eng: So, Ānanda, don’t be judgmental about individuals.

an6.44:16.8.eng: Those who pass judgment on individuals harm themselves.

an6.44:16.9.pli: Ahaṃ vā, ānanda, puggalesu pamāṇaṃ gaṇheyyaṃ, yo vā panassa mādiso.
an6.44:16.9.eng: I, or someone like me, may pass judgment on individuals.

an6.44:17.1.pli: Kā cānanda, migasālā upāsikā bālā abyattā ammakā ammakapaññā, ke ca purisapuggalaparopariyañāṇe.
an6.44:17.1.eng: Who is this laywoman Migasālā, a foolish incompetent aunty, with an aunty’s wit? And who is it that knows how to assess individual persons?

an6.44:17.2.pli: Ime kho, ānanda, cha puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an6.44:17.2.eng: These six individuals are found in the world.

an6.44:18.1.pli: Yathārūpena, ānanda, sīlena purāṇo samannāgato ahosi, tathārūpena sīlena isidatto samannāgato abhavissa. Nayidha purāṇo isidattassa gatimpi aññassa.
an6.44:18.1.eng: If Isidatta had achieved Purāṇa’s level of ethical conduct, Purāṇa could not have even known Isidatta’s destination.

an6.44:18.2.pli: Yathārūpāya ca, ānanda, paññāya isidatto samannāgato ahosi, tathārūpāya paññāya purāṇo samannāgato abhavissa. Nayidha isidatto purāṇassa gatimpi aññassa.
an6.44:18.2.eng: And if Purāṇa had achieved Isidatta’s level of wisdom, Isidatta could not have even known Purāṇa’s destination.

an6.44:18.3.pli: Iti kho, ānanda, ime puggalā ubho ekaṅgahīnā”ti.
an6.44:18.3.eng: So both individuals were lacking in one respect.”

an6.45:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, isn’t poverty suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”

an6.45:2.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, daliddo assako anāḷhiko iṇaṃ ādiyati, iṇādānampi, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ lokasmiṃ kāmabhogino”ti?
an6.45:2.1.eng: “When a poor, penniless person falls into debt, isn’t being in debt also suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”

an6.45:3.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, daliddo assako anāḷhiko iṇaṃ ādiyitvā vaḍḍhiṃ paṭissuṇāti, vaḍḍhipi, bhikkhave, dukkhā lokasmiṃ kāmabhogino”ti?
an6.45:3.1.eng: “When a poor person who has fallen into debt agrees to pay interest, isn’t the interest also suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”

an6.45:4.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, daliddo assako anāḷhiko vaḍḍhiṃ paṭissuṇitvā kālābhataṃ vaḍḍhiṃ na deti, codentipi naṃ;
an6.45:4.1.eng: “When a poor person who has fallen into debt and agreed to pay interest fails to pay it when it falls due, they get a warning.

an6.45:4.2.eng: Isn’t being warned suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”

an6.45:5.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, daliddo assako anāḷhiko codiyamāno na deti, anucarantipi naṃ;
an6.45:5.1.eng: “When a poor person fails to pay after getting a warning, they’re prosecuted.

an6.45:5.2.eng: Isn’t being prosecuted suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”

an6.45:6.1.pli: “Yampi, bhikkhave, daliddo assako anāḷhiko anucariyamāno na deti, bandhantipi naṃ;
an6.45:6.1.eng: “When a poor person fails to pay after being prosecuted, they’re imprisoned.

an6.45:6.2.eng: Isn’t being imprisoned suffering in the world for a person who enjoys sensual pleasures?”

an6.45:7.1.pli: “Iti kho, bhikkhave, dāliddiyampi dukkhaṃ lokasmiṃ kāmabhogino, iṇādānampi dukkhaṃ lokasmiṃ kāmabhogino, vaḍḍhipi dukkhā lokasmiṃ kāmabhogino, codanāpi dukkhā lokasmiṃ kāmabhogino, anucariyāpi dukkhā lokasmiṃ kāmabhogino, bandhanampi dukkhaṃ lokasmiṃ kāmabhogino;
an6.45:7.1.eng: “So mendicants, poverty, debt, interest, warnings, prosecution, and imprisonment are suffering in the world for those who enjoy sensual pleasures.

an6.45:7.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci saddhā natthi kusalesu dhammesu, hirī natthi kusalesu dhammesu, ottappaṃ natthi kusalesu dhammesu, vīriyaṃ natthi kusalesu dhammesu, paññā natthi kusalesu dhammesu—
an6.45:7.2.eng: In the same way, whoever has no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, and wisdom when it comes to skillful qualities

an6.45:7.3.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, ariyassa vinaye daliddo assako anāḷhiko.
an6.45:7.3.eng: is called poor and penniless in the training of the Noble One.

an6.45:8.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, daliddo assako anāḷhiko saddhāya asati kusalesu dhammesu, hiriyā asati kusalesu dhammesu, ottappe asati kusalesu dhammesu, vīriye asati kusalesu dhammesu, paññāya asati kusalesu dhammesu, kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
an6.45:8.1.eng: Since they have no faith, conscience, prudence, energy, or wisdom when it comes to skillful qualities, they do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

an6.45:8.2.eng: This is how they’re in debt, I say.

an6.45:9.1.pli: So tassa kāyaduccaritassa paṭicchādanahetu pāpikaṃ icchaṃ paṇidahati.
an6.45:9.1.eng: In order to conceal the bad things they do by way of body, speech, and mind they harbor corrupt wishes.

an6.45:9.2.pli: ‘Mā maṃ jaññū’ti icchati, ‘mā maṃ jaññū’ti saṅkappati, ‘mā maṃ jaññū’ti vācaṃ bhāsati, ‘mā maṃ jaññū’ti kāyena parakkamati. So tassa vacīduccaritassa paṭicchādanahetu …pe… so tassa manoduccaritassa paṭicchādanahetu …pe… ‘mā maṃ jaññū’ti kāyena parakkamati.
an6.45:9.2.eng: They wish, plan, speak, and act with the thought: ‘May no-one find me out!’

an6.45:9.3.eng: This is how they pay interest, I say.

an6.45:10.1.eng: Good-hearted spiritual companions say this about them:

an6.45:10.2.eng: ‘This venerable acts like this, and behaves like that.’

an6.45:10.3.eng: This is how they’re warned, I say.

an6.45:11.1.pli: Tamenaṃ araññagataṃ vā rukkhamūlagataṃ vā suññāgāragataṃ vā vippaṭisārasahagatā pāpakā akusalavitakkā samudācaranti.
an6.45:11.1.eng: When they go to a wilderness, the root of a tree, or an empty hut, they’re beset by remorseful, unskillful thoughts.

an6.45:11.2.eng: This is how they’re prosecuted, I say.

an6.45:12.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhave, daliddo assako anāḷhiko kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā nirayabandhane vā bajjhati tiracchānayonibandhane vā.
an6.45:12.1.eng: That poor, penniless person has done bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re trapped in the prison of hell or the animal realm.

an6.45:12.2.pli: Nāhaṃ, bhikkhave, aññaṃ ekabandhanampi samanupassāmi evaṃdāruṇaṃ evaṅkaṭukaṃ evaṃantarāyakaraṃ anuttarassa yogakkhemassa adhigamāya, yathayidaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayabandhanaṃ vā tiracchānayonibandhanaṃ vāti.
an6.45:12.2.eng: I don’t see a single prison that’s as grim, as vicious, and such an obstacle to reaching the supreme sanctuary from the yoke as the prison of hell or the animal realm.

an6.45:13.1.eng: Poverty is said to be suffering in the world,

an6.45:13.2.eng: and so is being in debt.

an6.45:13.3.eng: A poor person who has fallen into debt

an6.45:13.4.eng: frets even when spending the loan.

an6.45:14.4.eng: for someone who prays for pleasure and possessions.

an6.45:15.1.eng: In the same way, in the noble one’s training

an6.45:16.4.eng: they wish, ‘May no-one find me out!’

an6.45:17.4.eng: on and on, life after life.

an6.45:18.3.eng: is a poor person who has fallen into debt,

an6.45:18.4.eng: and frets even when spending the loan.

an6.45:19.1.eng: And when in village or wilderness

an6.45:20.3.eng: goes to one of the animal realms,

an6.45:21.2.eng: from which the attentive are released.

an6.45:21.4.eng: with wealth that is properly earned.

an6.45:22.2.eng: holds a perfect hand on both counts:

an6.45:22.3.eng: welfare and benefit in this life,

an6.45:22.5.eng: This is how, for a householder,

an6.45:23.1.eng: In the same way, in the noble one’s training,

an6.45:24.3.eng: After gaining pleasure not of the flesh,

an6.45:25.1.eng: They give up the five hindrances,

an6.45:26.2.eng: regards the ending of all fetters,

an6.45:26.3.eng: by not grasping in any way,

an6.45:27.1.eng: To that unaffected one, rightly freed

an6.45:27.2.eng: with the end of the fetters of continued existence,

an6.45:28.4.eng: this is the highest freedom from debt.”

an6.46:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā mahācundo cetīsu viharati sayaṃjātiyaṃ.
an6.46:1.2.eng: At one time Venerable Mahācunda was staying in the land of the Cetis at Sahajāti.

an6.46:1.3.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā mahācundo bhikkhū āmantesi:

an6.46:1.5.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato mahācundassa paccassosuṃ.

an6.46:2.1.eng: “Take a case where mendicants who practice discernment of principles rebuke mendicants who practice absorption:

an6.46:2.2.pli: ‘ime pana jhāyinomhā, jhāyinomhāti jhāyanti pajjhāyanti nijjhāyanti avajjhāyanti.
an6.46:2.2.eng: ‘They say, “We practice absorption meditation! We practice absorption meditation!” And they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.

an6.46:2.3.pli: Kimime jhāyanti, kintime jhāyanti, kathaṃ ime jhāyantī’ti?
an6.46:2.3.eng: Why do they practice absorption meditation? In what way do they practice absorption meditation? How do they practice absorption meditation?’

an6.46:2.4.pli: Tattha dhammayogā ca bhikkhū nappasīdanti, jhāyī ca bhikkhū nappasīdanti, na ca bahujanahitāya paṭipannā honti bahujanasukhāya bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an6.46:2.4.eng: In this case the mendicants who practice discernment of principles are not inspired, and the mendicants who practice absorption are not inspired. And they’re not acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an6.46:3.1.pli: Idha panāvuso, jhāyī bhikkhū dhammayoge bhikkhū apasādenti:
an6.46:3.1.eng: Now, take a case where mendicants who practice absorption meditation rebuke mendicants who practice discernment of principles:

an6.46:3.2.pli: ‘ime pana dhammayogamhā, dhammayogamhāti uddhatā unnaḷā capalā mukharā vikiṇṇavācā muṭṭhassatī asampajānā asamāhitā vibbhantacittā pākatindriyā.
an6.46:3.2.eng: ‘They say, “We practice discernment of principles! We practice discernment of principles!” But they’re restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, loose-tongued, unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds and undisciplined faculties.

an6.46:3.3.pli: Kimime dhammayogā, kintime dhammayogā, kathaṃ ime dhammayogā’ti?
an6.46:3.3.eng: Why do they practice discernment of principles? In what way do they practice discernment of principles? How do they practice discernment of principles?’

an6.46:3.4.pli: Tattha jhāyī ca bhikkhū nappasīdanti, dhammayogā ca bhikkhū nappasīdanti, na ca bahujanahitāya paṭipannā honti bahujanasukhāya bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an6.46:3.4.eng: In this case the mendicants who practice absorption are not inspired, and the mendicants who practice discernment of principles are not inspired. And they’re not acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an6.46:4.1.pli: Idha panāvuso, dhammayogā bhikkhū dhammayogānaññeva bhikkhūnaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, no jhāyīnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti.
an6.46:4.1.eng: Now, take a case where mendicants who practice discernment of principles praise only others like them, not mendicants who practice absorption.

an6.46:4.2.pli: Tattha dhammayogā ca bhikkhū nappasīdanti, jhāyī ca bhikkhū nappasīdanti, na ca bahujanahitāya paṭipannā honti bahujanasukhāya bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an6.46:4.2.eng: In this case the mendicants who practice discernment of principles are not inspired, and the mendicants who practice absorption are not inspired. And they’re not acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an6.46:5.1.pli: Idha panāvuso, jhāyī bhikkhū jhāyīnaññeva bhikkhūnaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti, no dhammayogānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ vaṇṇaṃ bhāsanti.
an6.46:5.1.eng: And take a case where mendicants who practice absorption praise only others like them, not mendicants who practice discernment of principles.

an6.46:5.2.pli: Tattha jhāyī ca bhikkhū nappasīdanti, dhammayogā ca bhikkhū nappasīdanti, na ca bahujanahitāya paṭipannā honti bahujanasukhāya bahuno janassa atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṃ.
an6.46:5.2.eng: In this case the mendicants who practice absorption are not inspired, and the mendicants who practice discernment of principles are not inspired. And they’re not acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.

an6.46:6.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an6.46:6.2.eng: ‘As mendicants who practice discernment of principles, we will praise mendicants who practice absorption.’

an6.46:6.5.pli: Acchariyā hete, āvuso, puggalā dullabhā lokasmiṃ, ye amataṃ dhātuṃ kāyena phusitvā viharanti.
an6.46:6.5.eng: Because it’s incredibly rare to find individuals in the world who have direct meditative experience of the element free of death.

an6.46:7.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an6.46:7.2.eng: ‘As mendicants who practice absorption, we will praise mendicants who practice discernment of principles.’

an6.46:7.5.pli: Acchariyā hete, āvuso, puggalā dullabhā lokasmiṃ ye gambhīraṃ atthapadaṃ paññāya ativijjha passantī”ti.
an6.46:7.5.eng: Because it’s incredibly rare to find individuals in the world who see the meaning of a deep saying with penetrating wisdom.”

an6.47:1.1.pli: Atha kho moḷiyasīvako paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
an6.47:1.1.eng: And then the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

an6.47:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho moḷiyasīvako paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an6.47:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

an6.47:1.3.eng: “Sir, they speak of ‘a teaching apparent in the present life’.

an6.47:1.4.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti?
an6.47:1.4.eng: In what way is the teaching apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”

an6.47:2.1.pli: “Tena hi, sīvaka, taññevettha paṭipucchāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
an6.47:2.1.eng: “Well then, Sīvaka, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

an6.47:2.3.pli: santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ lobhaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ lobho’ti pajānāsi, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ lobhaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ lobho’ti pajānāsī”ti?
an6.47:2.3.eng: When there’s greed in you, do you understand ‘I have greed in me’? And when there’s no greed in you, do you understand ‘I have no greed in me’?”

an6.47:2.5.pli: “Yaṃ kho tvaṃ, sīvaka, santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ lobhaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ lobho’ti pajānāsi, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ lobhaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ lobho’ti pajānāsi—

an6.47:2.6.pli: evampi kho, sīvaka, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti …pe….
an6.47:2.6.eng: this is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

an6.47:3.6.pli: santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ mohadhammaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ mohadhammo’ti pajānāsi, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ mohadhammaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ mohadhammo’ti pajānāsī”ti?
an6.47:3.6.eng: When there are delusional ideas in you, do you understand ‘I have delusional ideas in me’? And when there are no delusional ideas in you, do you understand ‘I have no delusional ideas in me’?”

an6.47:3.8.pli: “Yaṃ kho tvaṃ, sīvaka, santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ mohadhammaṃ ‘atthi me ajjhattaṃ mohadhammo’ti pajānāsi, asantaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ mohadhammaṃ ‘natthi me ajjhattaṃ mohadhammo’ti pajānāsi—

an6.47:3.9.pli: evaṃ kho, sīvaka, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
an6.47:3.9.eng: this is how the teaching is apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”

an6.47:4.2.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ, bhante, bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
an6.47:4.2.eng: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
